Respirology Case Reports https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ ABSTRACT Paragonimiasis, a chronic zoonotic parasitic infection caused by Paragonimus Paragonimus Paragonimus We report a rare case of paragonimiasis initially presenting with trauma. Initial imaging and laboratory findings were predominantly indicative of trauma and nonspecific inflammatory responses, which obscured the clues of parasitic infection. The definitive diagnosis was achieved through comprehensive epidemiological history collection and parasitic detection in pleural fluid, highlighting the importance of considering parasitic diseases in cases with atypical infectious manifestations. case report eosinophils paragonimiasis pleural effusion traumatic fracture pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes source-schema-version-number 2.0 cover-date October 2025 details-of-publishers-convertor Converter:WILEY_ML3GV2_TO_JATSPMC version:6.6.4 mode:remove_FC converted:30.09.2025  M. Luo Y. Liu X. Yang M. Liu C. Yu Paragonimiasis Diagnosed Through Detection of Parasitic Ova in Pleural Effusion: A Clinical Case Report Respirology Case Reports 13 10 2025 e70354 10.1002/rcr2.70354  Associate Editor:  Funding: 1 Introduction Paragonimiasis is a foodborne parasitic disease caused by Paragonimus 1 2 2 3 1 2 4 5 6 This report describes a case diagnosed by detecting eggs in pleural effusion after trauma admission, highlighting that diagnosis requires integrating clinical, laboratory, imaging, and exposure history. Importantly, clinicians should remain alert to parasitic infection even without eosinophilia, and pleural effusion examination can be critical for timely diagnosis. 2 Case Report The patient is a 42‐year‐old male residing in Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture, Yunnan Province, China. On September 27, 2024, he presented to the emergency department with ‘head and chest trauma for 5 hours’, complaining of chest pain and difficulty breathing following an accidental fall. The initial diagnosis at the primary hospital was ‘rib fracture with massive pleural effusion’, but relevant examination data were missing. He was subsequently transferred to a higher‐level hospital, where the diagnosis included bilateral lung contusion, massive pleural effusion, and fractures of the 4th to 6th ribs on the right side. Blood tests showed elevated white blood cell count (12.28 × 10 9 Microscopic examination of pleural effusion and sputum revealed numerous typical Paragonimus eggs, golden‐yellow and elliptical (80–118) × (48–60) μm with an operculum and thickened posterior shell, consistent with the morphological features of Paragonimus (Figure 1 FIGURE 1  Paragonimus westermani Paragonimus Serum ELISA testing indicated positive IgG antibodies for Paragonimus 1 TABLE 1 Serologic results of parasitic antibody detection by ELISA. Item Detection method Result  Paragonimus ELISA Positive (+)  Schistosoma japonicum ELISA Negative (−)  Cysticercus ELISA Negative (−)  Echinococcus ELISA Negative (−)  Hymenolepis ELISA Negative (−)  Clonorchis ELISA Positive (+)  Gnathostoma ELISA Negative (−) RNA was extracted from pleural effusion and sputum, and specific primers were used to amplify the sequences. After comparison, the sequences showed 100% consistency with the Paragonimus Paragonimus 2 TABLE 2  Paragonimus ID Sequence 5.8S rRNA ITS2 CGAGGTCAGGAAAATGAGCCACATGGCACATATATAGGTCAGCATCGGACACACCACGCGCAACTTC AACCATAGATGATGACGGGACAGCGGAACGTGCACATAAATCATTCACTGAGCCACGACTCCGTTGCCACATCCCCATCAAGGCTTTCAGCCACAACATGGATACGCCCGGATTTGTTAGGGAAACGCCACAGATCTGGCACCCCACAGACACAAGGCCACGTTGGGGAAATCACGCCAGCTGGCAAAACCCAAGCCGCGACTTTTTGGGCGTCGCGATAGTTTATAAGCCGACCCTCGGACAGGCGTGGCCACAGGCTAACCCGTGGCCGCAATATA Chest X‐ray (Figure 2A 2B–F 2A,B 2E 2F FIGURE 2 CT scan results before chest treatment. Bilateral pulmonary lesions (red arrows) with a ‘tunnel sign’ (green arrows), pleural thickening/adhesions (blue arrows), and massive right pleural effusion (yellow arrows). Based on the patient's medical history, laboratory findings, imaging results, and molecular testing, a diagnosis of chronic thoracic‐pulmonary type Paragonimus 3A–D FIGURE 3 CT scan after thoracic treatment. Residual bilateral pulmonary lesions (A–D) with partial absorption, markedly reduced right pleural effusion, and improved pleural thickening. 3 Discussion Paragonimiasis is a food‐borne zoonotic parasitic disease prevalent in China and Southeast Asia. It is often caused by consuming undercooked freshwater crabs or crayfish containing metacercariae [ 6 Paragonimus westermani 7 8 8 9 10 11 Paragonimiasis and tuberculosis have similar clinical manifestations, with the key points for differentiation being that the former is accompanied by peripheral eosinophilia, lesions in the middle and lower lung fields, and migratory imaging findings, with pathology predominantly showing eosinophilic infiltration; the latter typically affects the upper lung fields, exhibits stable imaging, and presents with necrotizing granulomas on pathology [ 12 13 14 15 16 17 18 5 19 20 21 22 23 24 25 22 26 27 28 The patient in this case was admitted due to trauma, with initial imaging showing rib fractures and pleural effusion, which masked and delayed the diagnosis of underlying paragonimiasis. Laboratory tests indicated elevated white blood cells and neutrophils, consistent with general inflammation, but notably, peripheral blood eosinophils remained within the normal range. Previous studies have emphasised that eosinophilia is an important clue for paragonimiasis [ 5 CT scans of paragonimiasis commonly reveal five types of manifestations: inflammatory infiltration, peribronchitis‐like shadows, cystic shadows, pleural effusion, and cavities [ 29 5 Author Contributions Man Luo drafted the manuscript. Data collection and screening were conducted by Yang Liu and Xianyao Yang. Mei Liu and Chao Yu interpreted the data and revised the manuscript. Supervision and guidance were performed by Chao Yu. All authors rigorously reviewed the manuscript and approved the final version. Consent The authors declare that written informed consent was obtained for the publication of this manuscript and accompanying images using the form provided by the Journal. Conflicts of Interest The authors declare no conflicts of interest. Acknowledgements We are sincerely grateful to the patient and their family for granting permission to publish the information presented in this study. Data Availability Statement The data that supports the findings of this study are available in this article. References 1 Q.
